label: Gallows
column5: One gallows at a crossroads is clearly depicted on the Agas map outside the Postern Gate of the Tower of London.

label: Gallows Hill
column5: The site of Lydford Gaol gallows

label: Winters Gibbet
column8: marks the site where the corpse of murderer William Winter was once displayed in chains after his 1791 execution. The replica gibbet stands as a grim reminder of a crime that shocked the region and of the era’s belief in public punishment as moral deterrence.

label: Thomas Busby's Gallows
column5: Thomas Busby was executed by hanging near his inn in 1702 for murdering his father-in-law
column6: after which his body was displayed in chains at the crossroads. Before facing the gallows
column7: he cursed his favourite chair in the pub
column8: claiming anyone who sat in it would die violently — a legend that has endured for centuries.

label: Execution Dock
column5: Execution Dock in Wapping was the site where
column7: pirates and seafaring criminals were hanged under Admiralty law
column8: their gallows positioned below the Thames’ low-tide mark. Prisoners were paraded through London to the dock in a public spectacle led by the High Court Marshal carrying a silver oar

label: Caxton Gibbet
column6: located along the old Ermine Street near Cambridge
column7: is linked by folklore to the horrific practice of live gibbeting—leaving convicts to die slowly in iron cages. Though stories tell of a murderer and a compassionate baker both meeting this fate
column8: historical records suggest such executions at Caxton were likely legend rather than fact.

label: Combe Gibbet
column6: standing on Gallows Down in Berkshire
column7: was erected in 1676 to display the bodies of lovers George Broomham and Dorothy Newman after they murdered Broomham’s wife and son. Now a replica
column8: it has become a local landmark and the starting point for the annual Combe Gibbet Race
column9: blending grim history with modern recreation.

label: Bilstone Gibbet
column5: The Bilstone Gibbet in Leicestershire once displayed the body of John “Topsy Turvey” Massey
column6: a violent farmhand hanged in 1801 for murdering his wife after a drunken quarrel. The original
column8: said to evoke eerie sensations among locals who dare to approach it after dark.

label: Gibbet Stone
column6: believed to be the socket that once held a gibbet post
column7: was relocated in 1962 to the north side of the road by the Deeside Field Club. A plaque explains it originally stood on Gallows Hillock
column8: where local barons administered justice until their feudal powers ended in 1747.

label: Proctor's Ledge
column5: The most likely site of hangings during the Salem Witch Trials
